discourse_list.title: How Many Delegates Do This As Their Job?

content.content: I was looking at how much @Recognized-Delegates are paid. It seems like a full time salary. Which makes sense when you think about how complex Maker is. But I also think I heard in Discord or @rune’s calls or community call that most delegates are just part time. Does anyone know if this is true? I think someone said @flipflopflapdelegate and @GFXlabs and maybe another couple are full time and the others all just do it as a hobby or part time gig? Can the various delegates maybe chime in so we know which are working on Maker every day and which are just focused on knowing a few aspects? If not full time, which parts of the DAO do you try to be “expert” on? For simplicity, let’s call an average of 40 hours a week full time. Big thanks in advance. I think it would help small holders know who to delegate to. Also, it would be helpful to know what to think about the pretty high level of pay.

content.content: Hi @AliceinMKRland excellent observation - We at Flipside Crypto (assisted by @rspa) focus on Maker as one of our core delegations. We are a full-time Governance team focused on many L1s (Ethereum, Terra, Solana, Osmosis) and DAOs - concurrently beginning to expand into L2s. Maker is very time-intensive and is difficult to balance with other responsibilities. We believe in the merit of being involved in the governance of other DAOs and building valuable cross-network knowledge. We commit one full-time hire to focus on MakerDAO as a key responsibility for about 20 hours a week. As a Data Analytics organization and Governance team, we focus on decentralization, growth strategy, DAO infrastructure & tooling, and making Maker more accessible for all. We also view Maker as a luminary that can be shared as a model for other growing DAOs. Feel free to reach out for more!

content.content: I like to share that work of many delegates are beyond just postings on the forum. There’s a lot of unseen work such as attending calls (both public and private) as well as various proposal ideas, discussions (especially giving feedback to potential proposals by CUs), and submissions. Many including myself and @PaperImperium also work on educating various players (such as traditional finance and government officers) and promoting Dai and MakerDAO in several ways. Though to be honest, so far I never felt it like a job but more of a movement and a duty. In 10 years, we will be remembered. But in what way? As an interesting experiment that failed? Or a revolutionary standard of new finance? And that difference lies on both delegates, CUs, and the community’s hands.

content.content: Thanks for the mention. ACREinvest is a new DAO services business focused on Web 3 governance and social incentives. We are in the process of converting to a decentralized, community-owned services DAO (we call our flavor of DAO a “satellite DAO”). I work full-time 24/7 300% in Web3 as the founder of ACREinvest and co-founder of a tokenized community we sponsor called ACRE DAOs. ACRE DAOs is in the social DAO space comprised of folks interested in regenerative finance (ReFi) and how DAOs can use crypto asset investing and permissionless peer-to-peer markets for positive change in the real world. Being compensated as a Recognized Delegate is not a “job.” My personal time spent is an investment as an entrepreneur in a business proof-of-concept around a new industry of crypto governance services. A successful business model for the provision of such services will need to be found for any DeFi protocol or other DAO with significant Treasury resources to function productively and soundly at scale. My activities in the space are accordingly integrated and chosen strategically so that by cross-pollination and aligned contributions, ACREinvest can add meaningful value within all the ecosystems where I am active. Bringing “real world” Wall Street credentials and decades of experience as a New York admitted attorney - summary here, the compensation paid by the protocol is in no way comparable to my individual opportunity cost for what I would charge for legal services or salaries I could command in the private sector. Allocation of my time that is task-oriented for MakerDAO is dynamic and dependent on what’s needed to meet the minimum level of obligation for the Recognized Delegate role, plus whatever additional time makes sense in the grand big world of opportunity and long term impact I’d like to contribute to the project. Generally speaking, there are not the financial incentives currently in place to support the level of full-time engagement and subject matter expertise the DAO needs urgently today and in the future for governance and accountable C-suite type leadership. In terms of leadership, we have to radically re-think what accountable leadership looks like in a decentralized organization. I just did a Tweet storm sharing some resources and thoughts on this point.  twitter.com    kianga.eth 🌍 1000 ACRE DAOs in 1000 Days @fhomoney  Who (i.e., what kind of actor) is in the best position of trust to be responsible for understanding everything that’s happening & capable to communicate the information legibly to the various stakeholders in the@MakerDAO ecosystem (not just MKR holders)? forum.makerdao.com/t/acreinvest-d…   12:54 PM - 27 May 2022       Hope that’s helpful to the discussion here in this thread! Thanks for the opportunity.
